title.value: Autism incidence and spatial analysis in more than 7 million pupils in English schools: a retrospective, longitudinal, school registry study
title.justification: The title clearly states the focus on autism incidence and spatial analysis in English schools using a retrospective, longitudinal study design.
title.quote: Autism incidence and spatial analysis in more than 7 million pupils in English schools: a retrospective, longitudinal, school registry study

extractions.description: The paper investigates the incidence of autism among school-aged children in England, analyzing the impact of geographic and sociodemographic factors on autism diagnoses. It utilizes data from the National Pupil Database and employs mixed-effects logistic regression to assess the influence of various factors on autism incidence over the period 2014-2017.

type.justification: The study uses actual data collected from a government registry to analyze and draw conclusions about autism incidence in England.
type.quote: In this retrospective, longitudinal, school registry study, we sourced data for the years 2014â€“17 from the summer school census, which is a component of the National Pupil Database.

name.justification: The research focuses on the incidence and distribution of autism, which is a common subject in epidemiological studies.
name.quote: Understanding how certain factors affect autism incidence can help to identify inequities in diagnostic access.

name.justification: The study examines public health service boundaries and their impact on autism diagnoses, tying into broader public health concerns.
name.quote: The incidence of autism varies across sex, age, ethnicity, and geographical location.

name.justification: The dataset is the primary source of data used for analyzing autism incidence among pupils.
name.quote: We sourced data from the National Pupil Database, which is a government registry that collects information about all pupils under state education in England.

referenced_paper_title.value: Association of race/ethnicity and social disadvantage with autism prevalence in 7 million school children in England
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is extensively used in the study to analyze autism incidence across sociodemographic groups.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We sourced data from the National Pupil Database, which is a government registry... our study was approved by the ethics committee...University of Cambridge.
